title: Should bank shareholders take one for the team?
text:
But the core of the tension between bankers, politicians and regulators over what spread over the cash rate they should charge mortgage customers has never changed.

It has and always will come down to what is the appropriate return on equity for the dominant bank.

At some setting, the banks can rightly be accused of profiteering because they can use their market power to charge a higher than appropriate rate.

In that case there’s a transfer from its customers to its shareholders that is detrimental to the economy.

The sensitivity to falling bank profits is likely to be felt most by shareholders, such as retirees.

But if the return is too low, then the banks cannot generate sufficient capital to protect against losses and that in turn leads credit rating agencies to reconsider their ratings, leading to higher funding costs.

They therefore cannot lend as freely and borrow as cheaply, hurting the system overall.

But what is that level? Above what return on equity can we confidently deride the banks for profiteering?

Advertisement

That is hard to answer. But the view of politicians, and it seems the central bank, is that the major banks can operate just fine at a reduced return on equity, given they remain among the most profitable lenders in the world.

Yes, the reduction in the cash rate to below 1 per cent will crimp their net interest margins. That's because the profits they make lending out free deposits fall just as falling bond yields further reduces interest income.

But policymakers seem to have the view that if ROEs shift from around 12 per cent to 10 per cent or lower, the system will handle it just fine. And if that reduction in profitability is distributed into the economy via lower lending rates, the economy in aggregate is better off, they would argue.

Shareholder trade-off

The sensitivity to falling bank profits is likely to be felt most by shareholders, such as retirees, who rely on the dividend income generated by those profits. As we are reminded by the banks, we are all shareholders via our superannuation funds.

But for society in aggregate this is a trade-off we have made before.

In 2014, David Murray concluded as part of the Financial System Inquiry that in order to reduce the risk and cost of an expensive taxpayer funded bail-out, our banks should be unquestionably strong by global standards. To do this would require raising more equity capital, reducing returns on equity.

But Murray believed that the dividends generated by the banks should be considered more valuable, because profits from stronger banks were more sustainable.

Advertisement

The debate is similar now. Bank profits will come under threat from falling interest rates, and therefore so will dividends that their investors rely upon.

But this is an environment where bank depositors and investors in government bonds have had their incomes slashed to almost zero.

As a margin above deposit and bond rates, Australian bank dividend yields are actually extraordinarily high.

The earnings yield of the banks is up from 2.5 per cent above the bond rate to almost 8 per cent. While the dividend yield was 1 per cent above term deposit rates in 2010, and got up to 2.5 per cent in 2016, today it's over 3.5 per cent.

For this reason, the net effect of lower interest rates is to lower bank profits but to make the income they generate more valuable. In a relative sense there are reasons why the banks remain an investment that should hold its value.

The real losers

Of course, one cannot eat relative returns. And for both savers and investors the absolute reduction in income poses a challenge.

The real wealth transfer, as it always has been when the central bank eases policy, is from prudent savers to profligate borrowers.

Advertisement

Inevitably, savers will either have to eat into their capital or risk more of it to finance the same amount of consumption.

What also appears inevitable is another interest rate cut. Morgan Stanley analysts have previously predicted the banks may not be able to pass on much of another reduction if they are to maintain their profits.

That will no doubt spark another round of outrage in which everyone will fight their corner.

The Coalition wants a strong economy without having to threaten a surplus and wants monetary policy to work as hard as possible. A bit of bank bashing never hurt a politician, either.

The Reserve Bank has a job to restore inflation to its target, doesn't want a credit downturn on its watch and wants the banks to cooperate as much as possible to increase the effectiveness of monetary policy.

And the banks naturally want to be as profitable as the environment allows them to be.

Whether that's too profitable or not profitable enough will always depend on who you ask.
description: An interest rate cut has sparked predictable outrage as to whether the banks' actions are justified.
